ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Improved my French skills, gave me good opportunity to practice my film analysis skills, and helped me analyze film in a broader social and political setting.

gained history in the french new wave and other global second cinema movements. a found emphasis on decolonization across africa which was really compelling to learn about in conjunction with the french cinema.
Film critique, film analysis, sequence analysis

I learned how to write about film. I have always been interested in film criticism, and this was a helpful guide. 
I learned about France and the French speaking world in the 1960's, a lot of history and theory, which was great to get reintroduced to

I learned how to talk about film, and how to become a film theorist on paper and in conversation

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Very good course, the Professor is extremely knowledgeable and engages the class well. Films are well selected to broaden the conception of Francophone film. I would recommend moving discussion sections to a different moment (not after the screenings) because it is hard to make it through that 3 hour session.
Like any film course, evening screenings are easy to feel fatigued in even if the films themselves are fantastic...
The seminar format is perfect for discussion.

Strengths - great film screenings, a lot of really interesting films watched every week 
great lectures and presentations, really good reading material, also all the films were well documented and accessible    

weaknesses - while I appreciated a lot of films to watch every week, not all of the films ended up in the lecture  which seemed a little odd

On Thursday evenings we divided into two groups, English speakers and French speakers, it would for been nice to meet as a group on a few occasions

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Great course, I enjoyed it expanded my horizons in film.
Absolutely--particularly if the have a preexisting interest in cinema, history, and cultural studies! This course was very interesting and exciting, and the discussions were always great
Yes! For anyone interested in film and French film in particular

Yes I would recommend this course to anyone interested in the subject matter regardless of their prior experience with film, French and Francophone history/culture, etc. It was very accessible and it was especially helpful that the assignment expectations and goals were very well-defined.

Yes! this course is great for students across all disciplines. 
You also learn a lot about film and colonization history in the French 1960's 
film theorist and what defines a wave
